snippet.textDisplay:
First, EVERYONE and ANYONE who ever even looks at touching a lathe, should go find the Chinese factory worker who was killed by one video on Liveleak. This was an even heavier industrial lathe, he was caught in and it pulled his entire body through the 6" gap between the work and table. He looked OK for a few seconds after coming back out on the other side. The most alarming part was people in the comments thinking he seemed OK, not understanding that basically every bone and organ in his body had been destroyed by the compression of squeezing through that small space.
By far the best cautionary video once you understand what happened. Also highly recommended to look up the young woman who was killed by a lathe a few years back. A better understanding and awareness of what machines can potentially do is always good, even if it's hard to look at it.



Humans are not adapted to have a proper awareness of movement of rotation. Normal moving objects (at not too high speeds) your eyes and brain register, and heighten your alertness. A rotating object usually appears to be standing still, despite having enormous amounts of energy in the rotation. Rotation of that type basically doesn't happen in nature, so there is no extra mechanism built in to recognize it. Even simple and familiar things like a bicycle wheel that you just spun up by hand can create severe injuries especially if you get caught in gearing...


Also related is people walking into props on aircraft etc, despite knowing in their head just how dangerous they are if you ask them. Your brain simply doesn't register the danger properly while you're focused on doing other things, you have to consciously keep the danger forefront in your mind when around such equipment.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm glad you could call your mom and I'm sorry for the PTSD you got from this accident. You already know that most of injuries that makers experience is indeed from cleaning or reassembly, so thank you for sharing it with everyone.
My father been a carpenter, maker and survivalist since about 1976 and was never injured. Never... just until recently, around 3 years ago, where he cut his finger off (reattached, but not fully functioning) while cleaning some garbage.

snippet.textDisplay: Adam, thank you for sharing your experiences with us.  I'm sure you have prevented someone else from hurting themselves.  I'm so glad you still have your finger and hand.  I've grown up with you as an inspiration and would have given you my own finger had you needed it.  I've spend a lot of time in a machine shop, mills and lathes had always had my extreme respect, so it has been other tools that have drawn blood.  I surface ground a few thou off the back of my hand wiping a magnet.  I also lost a finger nail to the belt sander (keep the rest adjusted).  I have cut myself pretty badly when pulling long chips out of the lathe during cleaning.  Stay safe!

snippet.textDisplay:
I hurt myself with a table saw. I was incredibly lucky: I didn't lose my finger, and the fingernail grew back relatively normally. It was all a stupid mistake, on the last cut of the day before I shut everything down and had dinner.


I still get shivers, quick heartbeat, and anxiety thinking about the accident, how badly it could have turned out if things had gone slightly differently. I have occasional nightmares. Some lessons are hard to learn, and really stick with you.

snippet.textDisplay:
Precisely why old large industrial machines scare the crap out of me. They will take a finger and not miss a beat.
I have an old drill press with a loose belt. The drilling ability isn't so good because of this, but if something happens the belt slips before it can hurt me.
Every time I think about ordering a new belt, I remember than at full strength this thing could cause serious harm. Thanks for reinforcing my thoughts with your video. I can tell it was hard for you, but I'm proud you did it.

snippet.textDisplay: Yep! I've done this too.. I was turning a part and thought I'd give it a clean with a piece of sandpaper when I wrapped it around forming a U shape at which point the top grabbed and rolled under the bottom pulling my thumb in with it.. I was okay but it's been one of a few close calls and it made me have a lot more respect for that unforgiving machine. snippet.textDisplay: I understand the shame you spoke of. I used to run a CNC horizontal boring mill years ago. I was running a part with large holes with .0002 in tolerances. The spindle was running 400rpm with a boring bar. Usually, the spindle shut off after it completed, but I overrode it as I had to adjust the bar and rerun the pass. I was checking it with the dial bore gauge and accidentally backed into the boring bar. It grabbed the leg of my pants and cut the back of my leg, then proceeded to twist the pant leg. I pulled back and they ripped all the way down to the ankle and continued to twist. I finally jerked back as hard as I could and ripped the pant leg off entirely. I then stood there (I was in a room by myself), with blood running down my leg and all I could think of was, what am I going to do now? I don’t want the guys to see me like this. I finally go someone to get the boss. He came back white as a ghost and said, sit down and let me see how you are. All I said was, please just get me some pants! You have to respect machines at all times, this thing could have ripped my leg off easily.

snippet.textDisplay: Adam’s so right that the pain receptors will shut down at that “moment”. I had a similar injury as a maker. I was assembling back a large brushless outrunner motor which I took apart (to hammer its shaft out of the stator to have it coming out at the top of the rotating-can), and BAM!! The two motor halves snapped together suddenly as the shaft got aligned with the bearings. The sheer force of magnetic attraction ripped my finger in a split second. Fortunately, I only had a dangling piece of flesh, not a dangling finger. But that moment was super intense especially with seeing all that blood running down the wrist before seeing what happened to the finger.

snippet.textDisplay: Few shop tools have as many ways to maim and kill as a lathe. Saw a video just the other day about a guy wearing gloves that got his hand sucked in, held the belt driven turret with his other arm, with the belts smoking (good thing they were loose), for over 20 minutes before someone came to his rescue and turned the machine off - arm and hand broken, but not lost. Fear the lathe, respect the lathe.

snippet.textDisplay: Adam.....I lost an arm 30ish years ago following a motorbike accident. I don't have any memories of the accident, and its pretty unclear if it was me or the truck that run over me and my bike was to blame....but I kinda always felt some of the stupidity that resulted in the loss was mine.  I physically recovered, and after 6 months I was back at work and pretty much everything was back to normal. a few months later I mentally fell apart...I was diagnosed with PTSD. getting past the PTSD was much harder than loosing the arm.....I found telling my story helped....even though I didn't want to....at least in the beginning.... I hope this video does the same to you :)

snippet.textDisplay:
I was at a discussion with Blacksmiths, and one of the masters had a friend that, when he was tired, was polishing a knife he made. one moment of inattention and the polishing wheel had snatched the blade and threw it straight through his femoral artery.
time and time again,I'm told by every maker that it's never the heavy-hitting machines or corrosive materials that hurt you, it's the fastest moving ones; the ones you can't react to fast enough. I'm glad you're okay Adam.

snippet.textDisplay:
You know when you're changing a bike tire and you spin the pedals so the wheels go really fast and then when it slows down you reach out your hand to stop it completely? Used to work with a guy who did that exact thing, except it wasn't a bike tire, it was a chainsaw. Somehow he did not lose anything but the sensation in all of his fingers.

I've been in machine shops where they don't even allow gloves in the same room as the lathes and belt sanders and such.

You also could have lost your life if it caught you good enough and ate your arm to your shoulder. I've seen that happen.


I've seen enough videos of people getting caught in machinery to know that shit ain't nothing to fuck with.


You should really REALLY take off your watch and ring when you're dealing with circular machinery. Be it saws to lathes.


You really need to remove those when in the shop. Even if it's sentimental, like the ring, just put it in your pocket.


It can be an excuse to get a cool pocket watch to replace the wrist watch.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel like even with the shame and all that you missed a point, and bear in mine my mantra has always been "safety second, the job comes first'. That being said, injuries can happen to makers, builders and all professions and hobbies but they shouldn't be happening after 2 years of experience, they definitely shouldn't be happening after 10 nevermind your 40+ years. I had a chain saw blade wrap round my arm when I was 25, and it taught me a lesson I never forgot, I've not had injuries that required stitches or more since.  And with yourself this is the worrying side of the way you work, how many videos do you acknowledge you should be using ppe and then just dont. Complacency kills, and you seem complacent about alot of safety. I'm glad your ok, I hope you finally do what you preach!

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you so much for sharing this. It is a hard topic, and it is so very embarrassing. I made a mistake in this vein myself, when I was changing tool in a mill with M-code. This required me to catch the tool as the machine lets go of it, so I'll usually always grip it fully and then punch in M6 for the tool change. This time I missed the 6, and pressed 3 instead. M3 is spindle start.
I was very lucky in that I was wearing gloves at the time, because the mill just ripped my glove off my hand, but my hand was unscathed.


This too is a lesson for anyone who uses CNC with manual tool change. Double check your codes when your body is on the line. Stay safe out there.

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve worked in the restaurant industry for almost a decade now and for a long time I would listen to audiobooks while I prepped my station, and more times than I would care to admit I’ve cut off a fingernail or a small piece of finger while cutting down some steaks just from being to comfortable with an action and not paying enough attention. Just careless mistakes. I’ve cut no telling how many hundreds or maybe even thousands of steaks at this point. It’s mindless muscle memory a lot of the time. But I can’t forget I’m also holding an extremely sharp blade at the same time, and that it takes almost no effort to cut through flesh 😂

snippet.textDisplay: I let my guard down with a drill press once. It was one that I had not used before and it had way more torque than I thought it would have and the work got ripped out of the work holder that was available that was not suitable to the task and that I only thought I understood how it worked. the spinning piece of square tube I was drilling lacerated my had when it pulled out. I knew better than to drill metal without a proper vise but I was too comfortable with using shop tools and forgot that drill presses can be dangerous. It happens and it is always embarrassing

snippet.textDisplay: When I was 13, I was helping my father lower his tool chest out of the Uhaul into my uncle’s drive (we had just moved to Florida after my father lost his position at GM as a sheet metal specialist). I had ignorantly wrapped the poly rope we were using to lower the chest out of the truck around my hand, which then ran through the d ring in the truck wall to the chest on the ramp. When the weight of the chest overcame my strength (it was in excess of 800 lbs loaded), my hand got yanked towards the ring. Panicked, my father told me to let go. Ten feet of rope burned a groove 1/4 of an inch deep across the back of my hand, which was certainly better than having my fingers torn off by hitting that ring. I’m 45 now, but my father still tears up at the idea that I may have lost a hand because of his perceived mistake (not warning me to not wrap the rope around my hand). We all live and learn Adam... 🙂

snippet.textDisplay:
I was working at an industrial site and one person made a little mistake and broke their ankle. They shut down work for a full day to drill into the heads of 1500-2000 workers to be safe. Because they know from the past that if small accidents happen, that big accidents aren't too far away if other people get careless.

I wonder if there is a manual or warning book of sorts about all of the things you shouldn't do with a lathe or ways that they can injure you. The close call I had was I left the wrench used to tighten down the part that spins in place, then adjusted the cutting bit and turned it on. The wrench got thrown with enough force that it would have been a bad injury if it hit me in the wrong place.

snippet.textDisplay: Wow, I relate to your story! When I was 18 I worked at my uncle's hardware store doing chainsaw repair. As part of this we buffed the grungy chains on a stationary wire wheel. A co-worker had upgraded it from a 1/2hp to a 2hp motor.  In my confidence of having done this many times, I paid no attention to the increased power and leaned into it.  The chain hooked the wire wheel and jerked out of my hands. I immediately looked at my hands and noticed that my right middle finger was shorter than the others! I grabbed it and held on tight while someone drove me to the local Dr.  A co-worker brought my finger piece a little later.  I was fortunate enough to get lined up with the premier hand Dr in the country at Merritt hospital near you in Oakland. My finger was reattached and is quite functional now 40yr later. A little crooked, but functional and happy to have it.
